title: Hopcroft–Karp algorithm
summary: In computer science, the Hopcroft–Karp algorithm (sometimes more accurately called the Hopcroft–Karp–Karzanov algorithm)[1] is an algorithm that takes a bipartite graph as input and produces  a maximum-cardinality matching as output — a set of as many edges as possible with the property that no two edges share an endpoint. It runs in O ( | E | | V | ) {\displaystyle O(|E|{\sqrt {|V|}})} time in the worst case, where E {\displaystyle E} is set of edges in the graph, V {\displaystyle V} is set of vertices of the graph, and it is assumed that | E | = Ω ( | V | ) {\displaystyle |E|=\Omega (|V|)} . In the case of dense graphs the time bound becomes O ( | V | 2.5 ) {\displaystyle O(|V|^{2.5})} , and for sparse random graphs it runs in time O ( | E | log ⁡ | V | ) {\displaystyle O(|E|\log |V|)} with high probability.[2]
